head.title: Elegy VII. The Dean.1, 1 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 23-28.22 [GT's note: The seat of the late unfortunate Earl of Kilmarnock.] Seat of the Boyd family, the Dean, known until 1700 as Kilmarnock Castle, and now as Dean Castle, is just north of the Kilmarnock town centre. The 4th Earl of Kilmarnock, William Boyd (1705-1746) joined the Jacobite rising in 1745 only after Charles Edward Stuart visited Callendar House, part of his wife’s inheritance. Convicted of treason, Boyd was beheaded August 18, 1746 on Tower Hill, and his estates forfeited. His eldest son, James, Lord Boyd, regained the estate in 1751.

l.emph: The mould’ring walls confess their beauty past,
A fragment falls with each revolving blast.

epigraph.bibl: McPherson.33 James Macpherson, The Highlander; A Poem: in Six Cantos (1758), p. 59. Turnbull substituted “revolving blast” for “invading blast.”

lg.l: Now, in the western main, the sun descends,
And gold’n clouds the low horizon bound,
The solemn night her sable robe extends,
And nature lies in silence hush’d around.
The lonely shepherd leaves the breezy hill,
And seeks the cottage to indulge repose,
The lover wanders by the winding rill,
To vent the mournful story of his woes.
Pale Luna gilds the plains and shady bow’rs,
The limpid streams reflect the silver ray,
Now fairies revel, in the silent hours,
But fly to distant lands, at break of day.
The night owl screams from out her lonely bow’r,
Where, all the day, she solitary reigns,
Whose voice directs me to yon aged tow’r,
To view of ruin’d grandeur the remains.
Ah me! how sad the tott’ring fabric stands,
Who shall preserve it further from decay?
Ah none! to other Lords belong its lands,
The antient name extinct and dy’d away.
That antient dome, which once with grandeur grac’d,
And proud magnificence o’erlook’d the plain,
Its tow’rs and lofty battlements defac’d,
All desolate and ruinous remain.
So stands an aged Chief, great in decay,
Forlorn and sunk beneath a load of years;
Yet, spite of time and locks of silver gray,
His youth majestic from his age appears.
The shaggy green her mould’ring walls deface,
And ivy wreaths her tott’ring turrets bind,
Impending fragments hang, in airy space,
In dire contention with the raging wind.
Where yonder stately ash, in verdure clad,
Extends her boughs outo’er the nodding wall,
There, round the table, gen’rous heroes fed,
While festive mirth resounded through the hall.
Ah! now no heroes those apartments grace,
Nor social mirth to cheer the dreary walls,
But airy phantoms roam from place to place,
And hold nocturnal revels in her halls.
Around the dome the raven and the owl,
The bat and bittern send a dreary cry,
The whistling winds through hollow caverns howl,
Startling the lonely trav’ller passing by.
Her gardens, once delightful to the eye,
With all that art and nature could adorn,
Now all o’erwhelm’d with prickly brambles lie,
A scene of ruin, dismal land forlorn.
No more is heard, within the verdant shade,
Th’ am’rous youth his secret vows impart,
In gentlest accents sooth the list’ning maid,
Urge his soft flame, and pour out all the heart.
The Muse who sung, delighted in the groves,
Gay as the bird, that carols on the spray,
Pensive, amid the dreary scene, she roves
And tunes to elegy the mournful lay.
And thou, lorn stream,may’st wail thy mantling bow’rs,
Where birds melodious oft renew’d the song,
And sadly echo through yon vaulted tow’rs,
And mourn in consort as thou roll’st along.
The aged oft with grief those ruins view,
While from their bosoms heaves the unbidden sigh,
Some relicts still their scenes of youth renew,
To stop the gushing tear, in vain they try.
Short is the date of ought the earth can boast,
Time ruins all with his corroding hand,
The princely palace, rear’d with mighty cost,
Ev’n brazen tow’rs cannot his rage withstand.
Where are the cities so well known to fame,

Ambition, nourisher of mighty wo,
Vainly upborn on pride’s high soaring wings,
The fatal source whence these disasters flow,
The fall of empires and the fate of Kings.
Here might the Muse, in humble strains, be bold
To tell the great, that all the direful spring
Of this sad mass of ruin they behold,

But she declines, the mournful tale to tell,
Of him who suffer’d in the hapless strife,
For why? the mournful story’s known too well,
His honour forfeit nor retain’d his life.
Yet shall remembrance oft renew the sigh,
To mourn the man so lov’d and so ador’d;
And when the curious trav’ller passeth by,
She’ll point the mansion of the hapless Lord.
